content: Piracy is as old as seagoing cargo. The issue isn't confined to Somolia, it's active in Polonesia, Micronesia, the Carribean and several other areas around the world. Wherever there is seagoing cargo and sympathetic port for disposing of the cargo, you'll have the problem. If the Somalis are more emboldened than others, it is because they KNOW the West will not intervene on the ground, since the last time they did, it failed miserably. Fighting piracy on the high seas is a poor method - akin to swatting flies instead of simply burying the rotting carcass they're coming from. The real 'solution' would be to impose a blockade on the Somali ports or capture them outright. An expensive and prohibitive measure, therefore we're stuck fighting them in a less than ideal manner. Sullivan013

content: First, the shipping companies and their insurers enable the piracy. Second, arming merchants is frowned upon by insurers, who see the loss of a couple million bucks preferable to a major fire on board a ship, causing the loss of ship and cargo (not to mention wrongful death suits of some sort, somewhere) Third, have you seen the size of the area we're talking about? The water off the coast of Somalia is freaking HUGE! This isn't like stopping piracy in the Chesapeake Bay. It's more like stopping piracy in the North Atlantic Ocean. Fourth, there is no effective government in Somalia. It is lawless. The fight against the Barbary pirates was a demi-war against nation states. The fight against the current Somali pirates is much more similar to a fight against terrorists, where the enemy is not clearly defined, and melts easily into a native population where positioning intelligence assets can be challenging. Give it some time. It is not so cut and dried as some of you seem to think it is. This is a pretty complicated problem with no simple solution. The only long term solution is a fully functioning government in the region around the horn, but that will take a lot of time, as well as money that we don't seem to have. How many of you would freak out and shriek bloody murder if we sent aid to Somalia in the intersts of furthering economic development so privacy is no longer a valued option?

Only ports where large vessels could be sent out to sea would need to be watched. The pirates use small motor boats for the actual hijacking. There are a lot of very serious problems for the world to deal with but stone age Somalia should not be one of them at sea.

content: Piracy is as old as seagoing cargo. The issue isn't confined to Somolia, it's active in Polonesia, Micronesia, the Carribean and several other areas around the world. Wherever there is seagoing cargo and sympathetic port for disposing of the cargo, you'll have the problem. If the Somalis are more emboldened than others, it is because they KNOW the West will not intervene on the ground, since the last time they did, it failed miserably. Fighting piracy on the high seas is a poor method - akin to swatting flies instead of simply burying the rotting carcass they're coming from. The real 'solution' would be to impose a blockade on the Somali ports or capture them outright. An expensive and prohibitive measure, therefore we're stuck fighting them in a less than ideal manner. Sullivan013

content: First, the shipping companies and their insurers enable the piracy. Second, arming merchants is frowned upon by insurers, who see the loss of a couple million bucks preferable to a major fire on board a ship, causing the loss of ship and cargo (not to mention wrongful death suits of some sort, somewhere) Third, have you seen the size of the area we're talking about? The water off the coast of Somalia is freaking HUGE! This isn't like stopping piracy in the Chesapeake Bay. It's more like stopping piracy in the North Atlantic Ocean. Fourth, there is no effective government in Somalia. It is lawless. The fight against the Barbary pirates was a demi-war against nation states. The fight against the current Somali pirates is much more similar to a fight against terrorists, where the enemy is not clearly defined, and melts easily into a native population where positioning intelligence assets can be challenging. Give it some time. It is not so cut and dried as some of you seem to think it is. This is a pretty complicated problem with no simple solution. The only long term solution is a fully functioning government in the region around the horn, but that will take a lot of time, as well as money that we don't seem to have. How many of you would freak out and shriek bloody murder if we sent aid to Somalia in the intersts of furthering economic development so privacy is no longer a valued option?

content: Piracy is as old as seagoing cargo. The issue isn't confined to Somolia, it's active in Polonesia, Micronesia, the Carribean and several other areas around the world. Wherever there is seagoing cargo and sympathetic port for disposing of the cargo, you'll have the problem. If the Somalis are more emboldened than others, it is because they KNOW the West will not intervene on the ground, since the last time they did, it failed miserably. Fighting piracy on the high seas is a poor method - akin to swatting flies instead of simply burying the rotting carcass they're coming from. The real 'solution' would be to impose a blockade on the Somali ports or capture them outright. An expensive and prohibitive measure, therefore we're stuck fighting them in a less than ideal manner. Sullivan013

content: First, the shipping companies and their insurers enable the piracy. Second, arming merchants is frowned upon by insurers, who see the loss of a couple million bucks preferable to a major fire on board a ship, causing the loss of ship and cargo (not to mention wrongful death suits of some sort, somewhere) Third, have you seen the size of the area we're talking about? The water off the coast of Somalia is freaking HUGE! This isn't like stopping piracy in the Chesapeake Bay. It's more like stopping piracy in the North Atlantic Ocean. Fourth, there is no effective government in Somalia. It is lawless. The fight against the Barbary pirates was a demi-war against nation states. The fight against the current Somali pirates is much more similar to a fight against terrorists, where the enemy is not clearly defined, and melts easily into a native population where positioning intelligence assets can be challenging. Give it some time. It is not so cut and dried as some of you seem to think it is. This is a pretty complicated problem with no simple solution. The only long term solution is a fully functioning government in the region around the horn, but that will take a lot of time, as well as money that we don't seem to have. How many of you would freak out and shriek bloody murder if we sent aid to Somalia in the intersts of furthering economic development so privacy is no longer a valued option?

content: I wonder how many warships it would take to blockade Somalia? Every navy in the world that has shipping in this area could pitch in. If they would that is. Only ports where large vessels could be sent out to sea would need to be watched. The pirates use small motor boats for the actual hijacking. Anything large enough to carry men and motor boats could be stopped, searched for weapons or put on the bottom if it resisted. There are a lot of very serious problems for the world to deal with but stone age Somalia should not be one of them at sea.
